data.title: Monster trucks roll into Van Andel Arena again
data.meta_description: Action begins Friday night and continues through the weekend.
data.text:
Ever wonder what’s going through Gary Porter’s mind when he is locked behind the wheel of Grave Digger, destroying everything that gets in his way during a Monster Jam show?

Think chaos.

"I can sit there and look at the track and plan this and plan that and hit this obstacle first, second and so on," said Porter, of Wadesboro, N.C. "But when I get into the truck and hit the first obstacle, it might twist the truck different than I planned. Sometimes I do a better job if I play it off the cuff.

"I just go out and hit the first obstacle and see what happens."

Grave Digger and a field of Monster Trucks are returning to Van Andel Arena for the Advance Auto Parts Monster Jam Thunder Nationals. Action begins 7 p.m. today, followed by shows at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Saturday and 2 p.m. Sunday.

MONSTER TRUCKS

What:

Advance Auto Parts Monster Jam Thunder Nationals

When:

7 tonight, 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Saturday and 7 p.m. Sunday

Where:

Van Andel Arena downtown

Appearing:

Trucks include Grave Digger, High Maintenance, Raminator, Rammunition and Spiderman

Tickets:

Available at

and the Van Andel Arena and DeVos Place box offices. Advance admission ranges from $16.50 to $41.50. Children 2-12 are $11.50 each show.

Porter started Monster Truck racing with the Carolina Crusher in 1985, before joining Grave Digger founder Dennis Anderson in 2001 to race for the sport’s most popular team. Porter will be breaking in a brand new $180,000 truck his team built for the 2011 season.

"I have a new No. 25 truck that we started running this year. It’s a nice piece and a new truck that people haven’t seen before," he said. "The body is the same and the engine is closer to the front. It has a shorter and narrower wheelbase than the No. 12 that I drove for nine years. It drives and handles a lot better."

Porter will be joined in Grand Rapids by hometown Wadesboro rival, Whit Tarlton, who races Spiderman. Tarlton, 41, only started competing five years ago, which is considered a late bloomer in the sport.

Tarlton previously worked in the forestry industry. Tarlton drove backloaders, taking rigs into the forests, where he would cut down trees, load them up and haul them to the mills.

But then Porter helped him break into the sport.

"I never thought about doing something like this," he said. "I never thought there would be a chance at it. Gary’s brother owned a 4-wheel drive shop, and they always did my 4-by-4s. I did the tire work on heavy equipment and did a lot of work for Gary.

"Monster Trucks run a lot faster than the skidders and logging equipment I used to drive. You mash the pedal to the floor in a piece of logging equipment and it isn’t going to jump into the air."
